title: Abel Prize for 2024 Won by Michel Talagrand for Studies of Universe’s Randomness
summary: Michel Talagrand of France has credited a brush with blindness for leading to the work that resulted in his recognition by the math equivalent of the Nobel Prize.

title: This Was Village Life in Britain 3,000 Years Ago
summary: The superbly preserved remains of a Bronze Age settlement offer a glimpse of a “colorful, rich, varied” domestic life circa 850 B.C.

title: Walter Massey, a Physicist With a Higher Calling
summary: He broke barriers as the first Black physicist in nearly every role. But his identity made him reach for dreams beyond his career as a scientist.

title: Penumbral Lunar Eclipse: How and When to Watch
summary: The subtle event, known as a penumbral eclipse, can be observed by everyone on Earth’s nightside.

title: Some Couples Are Choosing to Skip Sex and Go Straight to I.V.F.
summary: Well aware of how difficult conception or carrying a baby to term can be, some couples who hope to exercise a bit of control over an unpredictable experience are opting to do in vitro fertilization first.

title: Patients Hate ‘Forever’ Drugs. Are Ozempic and Wegovy Different?
summary: The new obesity drugs might be an exception to a chronic, deadly problem: the failure to stick with medication.

title: Preparing for a Total Solar Eclipse in Northern Maine
summary: Businesses and planning committees are eager for visitors, but some in remote Aroostook County are not sure how they feel about lying smack in the path of totality.

title: Prehistoric Amphibian Ancestor Is Named for Kermit the Frog
summary: The species seemed to have bug eyes and a smile, so a team of researchers named it Kermitops gratus in honor of the banjo-playing Muppet.

title: Overlooked No More: Yvonne Barr, Who Helped Discover a Cancer-Causing Virus
summary: A virologist, she worked with the pathologist Anthony Epstein, who died last month, in finding for the first time that a virus that could cause cancer. It’s known as the Epstein-Barr virus.

title: Surgeons Transplant Pig Kidney Into a Patient, a Medical Milestone
summary: The man continues to improve, doctors said. Organs from genetically engineered pigs one day may make dialysis obsolete.

title: Long Before Amsterdam’s Coffee Shops, There Were Hallucinogenic Seeds
summary: A nearly 2,000-year-old stash pouch provides the first evidence of the intentional use of a powerful psychedelic plant in Western Europe during the Roman Era.

title: Climate Change Made an Early Heat Wave in West Africa 10 Times as Likely
summary: Temperatures in the region rose above 40 degrees Celsius in February, with humidity pushing the heat index even higher.

title: Frans de Waal, Who Found the Origins of Morality in Apes, Dies at 75
summary: An unusually popular primatologist, he drew the attention of Newt Gingrich, Isabella Rossellini, the philosopher Peter Singer and the reading public.

title: More Studies by Columbia Cancer Researchers Are Retracted
summary: The studies, pulled because of copied data, illustrate the sluggishness of scientific publishers to address serious errors, experts said.

title: Following Measles Outbreaks, Officials Grow Wary of Renewed Threat
summary: Cases this year have already topped the total in 2023. Unvaccinated travelers account for most infections.

title: Geologists Make It Official: We’re Not in an ‘Anthropocene’ Epoch
summary: The field’s governing body ratified a vote by scientists on the contentious issue, ending a long effort to update the timeline of Earth’s history.

title: Total Solar Eclipse Safety: How to Watch Without Hurting Your Eyes
summary: A number of case studies published after recent total solar eclipses highlight the importance of safe viewing.

title: Study on ‘World’s Oldest Pyramid’ Is Retracted by Publisher
summary: The study, based on research featured in a Netflix documentary, fueled debate over a site that is used for Islamic and Hindu rituals.

title: At CERAWeek, Saudi Aramco C.E.O. Says Energy Transition ‘Visibly Failing’
summary: The comments by a Saudi executive raised questions regarding whose predictions about the future of oil and gas are more likely to be true.

title: The Unbearable Vagueness of Medical ‘Professionalism’
summary: Since its inception, this murky term has straddled the dual role of disciplining and inspiring.

title: All but 7 Countries on Earth Have Air Pollution Above WHO Standard
summary: New research found that fewer than 10 percent of countries and territories met World Health Organization guidelines for particulate matter pollution last year.

title: Thomas Stafford, 93, Commander of First U.S.-Soviet Space Mission, Dies
summary: The Apollo-Soyuz mission, amid the Cold War, broke new ground in space cooperation when an American capsule docked with a Soviet craft 140 miles above the earth.

title: Pandemic Lockdowns Had Varied Effects on Wildlife
summary: A new study of camera-trap images complicates the idea that all wildlife thrived during the Covid lockdowns.

title: New Havana Syndrome Studies Find No Evidence of Brain Injuries
summary: The findings from the National Institutes of Health are at odds with previous research that looked into the mysterious health incidents experienced by U.S. diplomats and spies.

title: Diagnosis of Princess Kate’s Cancer Followed Familiar Pattern, Doctors Say
summary: The Princess of Wales did not reveal the type of cancer she has, but oncologists say the disease is often identified during other procedures.

title: Living With a Messy Partner? Tips for Handling Different Organization Habits
summary: When people with different tolerances for clutter live together, things can get tense. Experts offer ways to find peace amid the piles.

title: A Psychedelics Reporter With a Changing Perspective
summary: Can an experimental drug cure opioid addiction? Andrew Jacobs, who writes about psychedelic medicine for The Times, explored the “promise and peril” of ibogaine.

title: When Medicaid Comes After the Family Home
summary: Federal law requires states to seek reimbursement from the assets, usually homes, of people who died after receiving benefits for long-term care.

title: Kent Campbell, Pivotal Figure in the Fight Against Malaria, Dies at 80
summary: Among his accomplishments in a four-decade career in public health, he helped pioneer programs providing bed nets in Africa.

title: The Surprise Ending of ‘Dune,’ the Popcorn Bucket
summary: What’s in the $24.99 tub, exactly? Lindsay Moyer, a nutritionist, reviews the contents of the movie-snack “vessel.”

title: Teen Pregnancy Linked to Risk of Earlier Death in Adulthood, Study Finds
summary: A large analysis in Canada finds that teenagers who had babies were twice as likely to die before age 31.
